events.target_title: Gnome 3.28 is always running in Xorg mode due to a crash in mutter (hybrid system)

note.body:
More observations (mutter 3.28.1 on Arch Linux):
1. If both nouveau and nvidia are blacklisted/unloaded GDM can start wayland session.
1. Otherwise it can only start X session.
1. If the dGPU is powered off via ACPI, entire system is locked and doesn't respond to anything but hard reset. However, it can be safely powered off after session is started (not sure about hibernation/sleep). This is more for #17, I guess.

events.target_title: No cursor upscale on 1.25 display of one-sized cursor theme

note.body: @vanvugt are you using cursor theme with frames of only one (small) size? For me the problem is that my cursor theme has only 32px frames. If I use default theme with 24px, 32px, 48px, 64px, 90px frames, it works seamlessly: when cursor moves between XWayland and Wayland (with scaled framebuffer) it doesn't change (visual) size.

events.target_title: No cursor upscale on 1.25 display of one-sized cursor theme

note.body: You can open it (smth like /usr/share/icons/<name>/cursors/left_ptr) in GIMP and see available sizes in frame names.

events.target_title: No cursor upscale on 1.25 display of one-sized cursor theme

note.body:
@vanvugt you can try usr/share/icons/Protozoa from [this Arch package](/uploads/ed56fc1930e5b4a06348b31e05c62c4d/xcursor-protozoa-20120114-1-any.pkg.tar.xz).

Mutter seems to want '24px' cursors for no scale. If this size is not available, it picks next one (for Protozoa it's '32px'). Note that actual frame size may be different.
For 1.25 mutter takes '48px' ('24px'×2) and scales it down to match actual size of '24px' (×1.25/2).
Thus to avoid this issue's problem for a time being I just upscaled (×2) frames, marked them as '48px' and merged with source frames.

[Similar screencast](/uploads/deb5f28078cd72752b985cb33b4d5743/test.webm) and [zenity-wayland-debug.log](/uploads/87bd636d147e9aec97a31fe0c1285240/zenity-wayland-debug.log).

Add touch screen input switch

note.body: As I understand it, this is for stationary but open/semi-open ("messy") environments where interaction is touchscreen-only but access needs to be restricted. It's common in retail and industrial settings where you may have a screen hooked up to a box controlling some kind of process.

events.target_title: Add touch screen input switch

note.body:
The patch was prompted by POS deployments, but it's a little more complicated since there are also tablets involved that do require DPMS/input off (@xiaoguang, please correct me if I'm wrong). I can't speak to the other reports in the original Bugzilla bug.

There are ways to work around this, but touching a screen to wake it up doesn't seem like a very far-fetched requirement and therefore something that might benefit from configurability at the GNOME level.

events.target_title: Add touch screen input switch

note.body:
> I don't understand. You want to be able to deploy the same OS on both tablets (which work fine as-is), and on static devices (which would work fine either with the config option, or by disabling screen locking), is that right?

That's my understanding, with the caveat that disabling screen locking may not be an option. The issue is more general though, and maybe best phrased as "I have this computer with touch input, the screen blanked and it became a brick."

> Touching the screen to wake it up might be something we can enable on systems that advertise themselves as desktop systems, I'd like to know what other OSes do in that field.

That makes sense to me. I don't know what other desktop OSes do by default, but so far I've found that Windows Phone had double-tap to wake, and some Android models have it too. But it's not quite the same thing, since those devices also have a button to wake them up making the gesture wakeup supplemental only.

Another thing I came across:

http://news.hopeindustrial.com/2014/waking-a-sleeping-pc-using-a-hope-industrial-touch-screen/

Also not /quite/ the same thing, since it's about waking up from hardware suspend and not blank, but it corroborates the use case since a user wouldn't necessarily differentiate between those.

> It's definitely an OS-deployment level config option though, not something that individual users would be interested in, and I don't think that adding more configurability is necessarily beneficial here, if there are other ways to solve the problem without adding more code.

Yeah, the best solution would be no configuration/customization at all. Next best is a system-wide setting.

There are two no-configuration options: Some kind of gesture like double-tap, or detect the situation where touch input is the only way to unblank. How reliably could we do the latter?

events.target_title: Add touch screen input switch

note.body: That could work, but what exactly qualifies as a built-in panel?

events.target_title: Add touch screen input switch

note.body:
> Currently: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/mutter/blob/master/src/backends/meta-monitor-manager.c#L2798

That heuristic would solve the issue for eGalax and similar solutions -- probably the vast majority of external screens with HDMI, DVI, DP, etc. input and USB touch output -- with minimal effort. I like it.

As Bastien points out, it would not help with tablets where the resume button is crippled somehow, and maybe there are corner cases where mobile devices are misidentified as immobile (you could in theory make one out of a RasPi, for instance), but I think those would be hard to support without an explicit setting somewhere.

events.target_title: Support compose sequences that produce two+ codepoints

note.body:
In order to use .XCompose, the input method should be changed to XIM (i.e. bypass gtk+). 

This report is about gtk+ being able to emit more than one codepoint.

events.target_title: Support compose sequences that produce two+ codepoints

note.body:
@sthibaul I think this issue describes what is necessary for GNOME/gtk#10

That is, if a compose sequence can produce two or more codepoints, then GNOME/gtk#10 is fully covered as well.

In addition, I do not think it would be accepted to fix the special case at GNOME/gtk#10, if the general case described here is not solved.

Therefore, I believe that GNOME/gtk#10 is a DUP of this issue.

note.body:
> @jwf which panels did you use the most?

@feaneron The networking panels (WiFi, Bluetooth) were the ones I found most valuable. I also used it to set account settings (e.g. profile picture) since I still use GDM and I'll see that when I start up my system.

Since I use GDM, there are some things that I must use gnome-control-center to change if I don't go searching for where a config file or some data is stored on my system. It would be nice to still use gnome-control-center for those things.

> gnome-control-center developers having to think about whether each panel would work under other desktops.

From my point of view, if something broke and stopped working in the panel because of a software incompatibility or missing library, I would accept my fate and I wouldn't direct that to the developer team. I think it is asking too much of you all to fix bugs or problems from using gnome-control-center in non-GNOME environments. But the control center was compatible before already, and this change makes it explicitly incompatible by policy.

> What change are you talking about though? The code was very similar.

I meant the change by adding the `OnlyShowIn=GNOME` tag to the `.desktop` file.

> I think, at this point, if you want to have it working again, you'll need to figure out how to bring it back.

Okay, that's fair. One question: if I make changes to the `.desktop` file myself, will the file be overwritten during upgrades? It would be a nice compromise to drop that line in the files and have it persist and not be overwritten. If not, then I think I'll move on to another tool since I am no longer using GNOME.

Thanks for considering this anyways.

events.target_title: Add a preview widget to "Open..." and "Save..." dialogs.
Add a preview widget to "Open..." and "Save..." dialogs.

note.body:
[Here's a slightly updated version of the patch](/uploads/e6fbfec45db6b6ca22ff23224cca6a79/add-preview-widget.patch), swapping stat for g_stat and removing GtkMisc.

As far as I can tell, there is no reason why this should not work for the "Open..." filechooser dialog--yet it does not.

There's also an issue of the margins allocated for the preview widget. Gtk doesn't seem to offer any means of limiting their size; ~~large images get scaled down in the preview, but are allocated oversized margins~~. EDIT: This is exasperated by using preview labels (whole filename is displayed with thumbnail, causing some files to have a large amount of empty space around their thumbnails); update pending.

events.target_title: Add a preview widget to "Open..." and "Save..." dialogs.

note.body:
[add-preview-widget.patch v3](/uploads/11fa7811f05118959f8e8b73b0bebf38/add-preview-widget.patch)

Renamed some things to more closely follow [the documentation](https://developer.gnome.org/gtk3/stable/GtkFileChooser.html), removed labels, moved some things around and made a few improvements for efficiency.

This version should add a preview widget to *every* filechooser dialog, and yet "Open.." dialogs still do not get one. Comparing my implementation to [various](https://github.com/GNOME/gimp/blob/master/app/widgets/gimpfiledialog.c) [other](https://github.com/elementary/mail/blob/master/src/client/dialogs/attachment-dialog.vala) [Gtk3](https://github.com/flatpak/xdg-desktop-portal-gtk/blob/master/src/filechooser.c) applications', it looks like everything is where it should be.

I am stumped.

events.target_title: Add a preview widget to "Open..." and "Save..." dialogs.

note.body:
Thank you for the reply.

Indeed, that is a lot more to do than I had in mind, and probably beyond my limited skillset. Nonetheless, epiphany needs preview widgets, as will many other applications if this approach is going to be applied across the board, so it's going to have to get done.

Let's [get that ball rolling](https://github.com/flatpak/xdg-desktop-portal/issues/237).

I notice that xdg-desktop-portal-gtk has its own [`update-preview` implementation](https://github.com/flatpak/xdg-desktop-portal-gtk/blob/master/src/filechooser.c#L431) and `GtkFileChooserNative` emits an [`update-preview` signal](https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk/blob/master/gtk/gtkfilechoosernative.c#L583).

If xdg-desktop-portal supported it, might these work as-is?

events.target_title: Add a preview widget to "Open..." and "Save..." dialogs.

Still not producing previews in "Open..." dialogs; not seeing anything in gdb about it.

I found that in function `gtk_im_context_xim_filter_keypress`, `context` is extracted into `context_xim` and gdb says this with regards to value
```gdb
$1 = {object = {parent_instance = {g_type_instance = {g_class = 0x555555ef2820}, ref_count = 1, qdata = 0x0}}, im_info = 0x0,                         
  locale = 0x555557491640 "en_IN.UTF-8", mb_charset = 0x555557491730 "UTF-8", client_window = 0x0, client_widget = 0x0, status_window = 0x0,          
  preedit_size = 0, preedit_length = 0, preedit_chars = 0x0, feedbacks = 0x0, preedit_cursor = 0, preedit_start_callback = {client_data = 0x0,        
    callback = 0x0}, preedit_done_callback = {client_data = 0x0, callback = 0x0}, preedit_draw_callback = {client_data = 0x0, callback = 0x0},        
  preedit_caret_callback = {client_data = 0x0, callback = 0x0}, status_start_callback = {client_data = 0x0, callback = 0x0}, status_done_callback = { 
    client_data = 0x0, callback = 0x0}, status_draw_callback = {client_data = 0x0, callback = 0x0}, string_conversion_callback = {client_data = 0x0,  
    callback = 0x0}, ic = 0x0, filter_key_release = 0, use_preedit = 1, finalizing = 0, in_toplevel = 0, has_focus = 1}

events.target_title: GtkTreeView with fixed height and list model doesn't redraw all elements if scrolled horizontally
GtkTreeView with fixed height and list model doesn't redraw all elements if scrolled horizontally

note.body:
I spent some time debugging GTK code, since I originally believed this to be an issue with Eclipse SWT usage of GTK. Here is what I found.

Whenever a row is changed with the fixed height mode (used by SWT for better performance), the following stack trace repaints items:

```
gdk_window_invalidate_maybe_recurse_full() at gdkwindow.c:4,483 0x7fffcedf4cbc	
gdk_window_invalidate_region_full() at gdkwindow.c:4,549 0x7fffcedf4e56	
gdk_window_invalidate_rect_full() at gdkwindow.c:4,257 0x7fffcedf4e56	
gtk_tree_view_node_queue_redraw() at gtktreeview.c:6,263 0x7fffcf405cbf	
gtk_tree_view_row_changed() at gtktreeview.c:9,006 0x7fffcf405cbf	
g_closure_invoke() at gclosure.c:804 0x7fffbf548968	
signal_emit_unlocked_R() at gsignal.c:3,635 0x7fffbf55aa7d	
g_signal_emit_valist() at gsignal.c:3,391 0x7fffbf562af1	
g_signal_emit() at gsignal.c:3,447 0x7fffbf562ddf	
gtk_tree_model_row_changed() at gtktreemodel.c:1,835 0x7fffcf3ec57e	
<...more frames...>	
```

The method `gdk_window_invalidate_maybe_recurse_full` will iterate over parent windows of the tree view (starting with `tree_view->priv->bin_window`) and will intersect their bounds. The direct parent window of the tree view has a negative `x` coordinate, if the tree is scrolled to the right. The more the tree is scrolled to the right, the lower the `x` coordinate value. The intersection of the windows then results in smaller and smaller repaint area, potentially resulting in no area at all.

events.target_title: [GTK4] GdkEvents being private breaks certain use cases

note.body:
For case 1, would such a gdk_display_create_button_press_event() API accept a GdkSurface as an argument? This is really the main use case we have: the ability to popup a menu at certain coordinates inside a GdkWindow/GdkSurface using a custom button press event. The event is created manually with that surface/window and is then fed to gtk_menu_popup_at_rect(). If specifying a GdkSurface to the new API is possible, then it's a perfectly acceptable alternative which we'd definitely make use of.

Some background info on why we even care about this: in SWT we dynamically build menus in higher levels of the stack. Essentially this means it's not always feasible to popup the menu right away using the current GdkEvent, or even by attaching it to the widget. I believe this rules out the GAction approach as well, as sometimes the menu hasn't been built at the time of the click/key press/etc.

Regarding case 2: I understand your concerns, and I agree. Could you expand a bit on how this would be accomplished using the accessibility layer? We have accessibility support in SWT so I would definitely like to explore this avenue further.

Gtk3 CSS background-image won't display  1 to 1 pixel by pixel
Gtk3 CSS background-image won't display  1 to 1 pixel by pixel

note.body:
I did some more testing: when I put my own icon into an icon theme and use 
`
-gtk-icon-source: -gtk-icontheme("comboBoxBeam");
`
and set the containing box to the size of the icon 
`
min-width:15px;
min-height:6px;
`
the icon displays well, pixel by pixel. But using url() or background-image, like in the examples above, it doesnt work. By playing with the size of the box or background-image size, it sometimes displays sharp or partly sharp. But there seems to be no tractable relationship between the size of the box and whether it displays well. (I tried eg same size, one pixel larger etc)

So yes I can use the first technique in some cases. but of course not all widgets have an 'icon' to set, unfortunately..

events.target_title: Gtk3 CSS background-image won't display  1 to 1 pixel by pixel

note.body: I'm for promoting it to bug ;)

events.target_title: Gtk3 CSS background-image won't display  1 to 1 pixel by pixel

note.body: aha yes clever, at least something I could try: so either even nr of pixels inside even or uneven inside uneven should draw sharp..

events.target_title: Gtk3 CSS background-image won't display  1 to 1 pixel by pixel

note.body:
Yes I just tried and that seems to be it ! :) Eg the enclosing button set to minimal size 21x21 will draw the 15x15 image properly, set to 20x21 it fuzzies. Hmmm yes of course the 'min-height' doesnt guarantee that the width will always be 21.. but its a start. Maybe in most cases for me that will suffice for my 'CDE' theme ;)

I searched a bit and indeed it seems to be a common problem in web design too. Solutions vary from exploiting browser specific side effects, eg apply something like 'translate(0,0)' to an element, because the translate will round to integer, or set a browser specific rendering option (-webkit-alias(0) or something like that). If that doesnt help they have to use javascript. In pure css it doesnt seem to be possible...

So anyway, thnx and yes, I'll close !

Jos

note.body: Is there any update on this issue? I recently tried to mount a NFS v4 share via nautilus, and it didn't work, nor did it work via the 'gio' command in the terminal. It did work just by using 'mount' just fine. Currently I mount my NFS share by using the '/etc/fstab' file. Implement type-ahead find for efficient file system navigation

note.body:
I think I might have a couple of fresh points to add here. 

I have been working without type-ahead for a couple months now. With `Full Text Search` disabled and `Search in subfolders: Never`, the experience is tolerable, but still far inferior to proper type-ahead. This is due, in part, to reasons related to those discussed above. For one, it's disorienting -- I don't want to lose sight of the other files in the current directory before I hit Enter. 

But there is a more concrete issue with this workaround: I would much rather *not* disable `Full Text Search` and set `Search in subfolders: Never`, because I *want* these features when I need to do a proper search of the filesystem. 

From what I can see, most commenters here are suggesting that type-ahead should be re-implemented as the default behavior. Clearly the maintainers are not interested. So what about an additional entry in the settings, disabled by default: `[ ] Use type-ahead navigation / Ctrl-f search`. Has this been considered? (I mean... I'm sure it has). I understand that this is a technical tool for tracking issues/bugs, but, if you would be so inclined @csoriano, could you tell us why this setting will not be implemented? Or, if the explanation already exits online somewhere, could you point me in that direction, or to the appropriate place to ask?

Edit: Ah, I now see that my points were mostly already mentioned in the Bugzilla comments. Oh well, now it's here too, and I couldn't find an explanation there for why this can't be re-implemented but off by default.

events.target_title: Implement type-ahead find for efficient file system navigation
Implement type-ahead find for efficient file system navigation

note.body:
>> I don't want to lose sight of the other entries in the directory before I hit enter

> Can you expand in use cases here? What is your end goal?

The use cases here are perhaps better described as exploration/examination of a directory than as navigation. Also "entries" might be the wrong word, I meant files and sub-folders, henceforth just "files". Traditional type-ahead provides a fast way to move around within a directory with many files. When the goal is exploration of a folder's contents, it is preferable that other files do not disappear when attempting to simply move the focus to a particular file. In some sense, if files are sorted by filename, the available functionality could be considered equivalent, although I still find it disorienting after a couple months of use. However if the files are sorted by something other than filename, the functionality is not there. Say I want to see which files were modified around the same time as "somefile.txt" -- sort by date modified, type "somefi", done. Not so with the current implementation.

Again, this is the less pressing of the two issues I listed.

>> I don't want to dig into the settings every time I need to do a proper search

> Not sure what you mean here, you always just search, nothing else. The end goal is to find a file.

In order emulate the convenience and speed of type-ahead in nautilus, the work-around is to use the settings I mentioned here [https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/nautilus/issues/244#note_99447]. Yes, I am aware of https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/nautilus/issues/247, but the issue of speed still remains when a directory is not yet indexed and/or there are subfolders lower in the directory tree which contain many files, and also `Full Text Search` still needs to be disabled. I do not want to change these settings in order to (almost) match the convenience of type-ahead, because I do not want to temporarily revert them when I need to do a recursive, full text search of the directory.

note.body: That's very nice to hear :) `fractal` could could use some command line arguments for stuff like this. For example, command line flags like `--username` and `--password` could help users of [other password store mechanisms](http://passwordstore.org/) like my self.

events.target_title: Error: `Can't store the password using libsecret`

note.body:
You were right @ArchangeGabriel, I had to `source /etc/X11/xinit/xinitrc.d/50-systemd-user.sh` as well as [suggested here](https://unix.stackexchange.com/a/295652/135796). What I've found out BTW is that I don't have to keep Seahorse installed and I removed it after the initial process and everything still works.

I've also found out that the program [`gkeyring`](https://launchpad.net/gkeyring) can provide the same functionalities as seahorse for command line users like me. I've managed to atomate the process of unlocking the keyring by putting in my `~/.xinitrc` the command `gkeyring --unlock --password="$(pass seahorse)"`

I guess I'm OK with my current setup, it has also solved the same [issue with Owncloud desktop client](https://github.com/owncloud/client/issues/6340).

events.target_title: Change clips speed

note.body:
I'm a new user to Pitivi, seems like it's more usable and easy than everything else I've tried (Shotcut, OpenShot, slowMoVideo). What I'm trying to accomplish is a time-lapse video, with segments of normal-speed time. In original form it's a 4 hour video, with probably 10 minutes where I'm actually speaking. I have tried splitting the clips, then selecting the clip to be time-lapsed. Then add the "Rate Adjuster" video effect. On a sample video only a few minutes long, this worked great to speed up the video. But the strange thing is the length of the clip is not shortened in the timeline. I would expect if I sped up a video to 5x speed, it would take 1/5 the space in the timeline.

In addition, upon exporting the video I discovered that audio is not adjusted at the same time. Audio seems to play at normal speed, while the video is accelerated. Once the accelerated clip completes, the normal-speed audio then plays for the remaining time with the last frame of the accelerated clip shown until the next clip begins.

I found there was a Sound Speed effect as well, but on a 2 minute clip it had taken my rendering time from ~5 minutes to ~1 hour. I haven't yet waited for it to complete. Is this the correct approach for creating a time-lapse video at this point?  Any idea if there's a way to speed up the audio speed effect or have the video and audio remain in-sync?

events.target_title: Allow notifications to be tuned
Inconsistent rules for shortcuts between different applications when switching keymaps

note.body:
Hello there,

I've got the same issue. With different layouts, but it's the same mechanism.
From what I've tested, here are my conclusions.

Apps using XWayland are fine. For example, in Gimp, Ctrl+N is working as expected (I mean the letter N in the current layout). In a Wayland app, it doesn't work.

When the shortcut is not working, the correct key is the one corresponding to the default layout configured in Gnome. For example, if my default layout is qwerty and I want to active Ctrl+N in bépo layout, I have to press Ctrl+'. ' is at the same position as N on a qwerty keyboard (keycode 78).

In Gnome-terminal, if I switch to the bépo layout and I try to change a shortcut in the preferences, when I press Ctrl+Shift+T, the scanned key is J (because T in bépo is J in qwerty).

If you keep only one layout, the keyboard shortcuts are working fine, no matter which layout you're using.

I hope this helps.

events.target_title: No folders listed if a STATUS response when listing them returns not found

note.body:
Here's the output of geary -d --log-network to the point at which I see the UI and the "missing folder" message. Does that help? I anonymized most of the file but kept the original version so I should be able to spot which folder is missing all along with the line timestamps...

note.body:
The way broadway works is by having basic input (keyboard & mice/touch) and output (screen) redirected. If specific OS stuff don't get in the way of that, it should be fine. One other spot I found is file open dialogs: if gtk decides to fire native ones, it'll appear on the native windows screen instead of browser. As I'm testing broadway on a remote computer, that was quite a surprise to see the file dialog on the wrong pc. I didn't try it yet, but I'm patching gtkfilechoosernativewin32.c with the same IS_WIN32_DISPLAY logic to see if it works.

I believe the GtkStatusIcon may misbehave (crash or appear on  the actual o/s/ dock, perhaps), but on the other hand I don't think broadway has a place to render that icon, anyway. I don't use it so I'll not bother looking.

Anywhere else, the native api (filesystem, etc.) is supposed to remain in place - someone could implement a "remote file choser" or something on broadway, but that's out of it's current scope, AFAIK.

fdo notification backend: Crashes when dbus call fails

note.body:
Hi @pwithnall, I managed to spend a bit of time on that. I'm not sure refcounting is the solution.

Let me explain the current behavior quickly:

1. A notification is send async, using `g_dbus_connection_call()`.
2. The **callback** is invoked:
  - if failure, we free/unref the notification.
  - if success however, we do nothing: we expect to receive a `notify` signal later on, in which we will free the notification.
3. The **notify** signal is received (only for notifications sent successfully), either because user closed the notification, or invoked an action associated with it. In any case, we free/unref the notification after handling the signal.

In the current implementation, there's no refcounting, we just do free. I replaced that by some refcounting, without changing the logic. And here's an example of what happens.

I fire a notification 5 times (1 per second).

In a first test case, the notifications are valid. GNOME Shell displays it. The refcount reaches 5. When ultimately I click to close the notification, I receive one `notify` signal. The refcount is now 4: the notification was leaked.

In a second test case, I tricked a bit to send invalid notification priorities, which make GNOME Shell crash. Somehow, the first notification is send successfully (the notification daemon answers before crashing), then the 4 following notifications are timeout (I guess the notification daemon is restarted, and our dbus connection is not valid anymore). The refcount reaches 5, then the callback is invoked 4 times (timeout), so the refcount is down to 1. The thing is: the first notification was sent successfully, but we will never receive a `notify` signal. So the notification is leaked.

It seems to me that introducing refcounting will just make things more tricky. The current implementation seems actually better: we free, remove from a list, and always check the list when we receive a signal, in case we freed the notification already. It's not super elegant but it does the job, and it just missed the little patch I submitted above to work in case of failure from the daemon.

Up to you, if you have other thoughts on that please let me know

events.target_title: fdo notification backend: Crashes when dbus call fails

note.body:
> Sounds like you also need to watch the owner of the `org.freedesktop.Notifications` name;

Interesting. I tried this approach, I used `g_bus_watch_name` and logged the details in `name_appeared` and `name_vanished` callback. Then I run some nasty code that crash the notification daemon in GNOME Shell. I forced glib to use the fdo backend, and then I exploit a weakness of the fdo notificatin daemon to crash it at will. I can clearly see the gnome-shell errors in the journal.

Surprisingly, on the client side, `name_vanished` is never invoked. Somehow, it looks like the dbus connection is left in an unusable state after the first notification is sent and trigger errors on the GNOME Shell side. Any additional notifications I send just times out.

Now if I restart my process, I can see in the `name_appeared` logs that the unique name is still the same. And once again, the first notification is send successfully, and the following notifications time out.

Just in case, here's some logs from GNOME Shell.

EDIT: some logs below where not related, I just removed it.

```
JS ERROR: Error: No property 'name' in property list (or its value was undefined)
FdoNotificationDaemon<._fallbackIconForNotificationData@resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/notificationDaemon.js:137
wrapper@resource:///org/gnome/gjs/modules/lang.js:178
FdoNotificationDaemon<._notifyForSource@resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/notificationDaemon.js:351
wrapper@resource:///org/gnome/gjs/modules/lang.js:178
FdoNotificationDaemon<.NotifyAsync/<@resource:///org/gnome/shell/ui/notificationDaemon.js:305
_proxyInvoker/asyncCallback@resource:///org/gnome/gjs/modules/overrides/Gio.js:90
```

I don't know how GJS handles this kind of error, but my guess is that it manages to recover, but leaves the dbus connection unusable somehow, and silently.

Is there any other signal I could watch, apart from watching names, to be notified of some kind of failure?

Horizontal scroll with touchpad does nothing

note.body:
Good news! I found another issue, maybe?  You say that on Linux, shift+scroll goes horizontally? In Windows (at least on my laptop), shift+scroll *scrolls one file independently*, disabling the linkage between the two editors, though it links back up when you scroll again without the modifier key.  I'm not sure if that was maybe intentional at some point (can't think why you'd want to necessarily do that?) but it's possible that it's an unintended consequence of differences in how the framework exposes scroll events.

One other wrinkle that might matter: this laptop uses "Precision Touchpad", which sometimes [emits events differently](https://developer.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-edge/platform/issues/7134034/) than a normal touchpad does.  I don't know if that extends to horizontal scroll or not.

Anyway, I see the same symptoms in `gitk` (which is built on `tcl`) so I'm guessing this is some low-level cross-platform issue.  Should I try to file an issue somewhere upstream?  Do you have any suggestions where to do so?

events.target_title: Horizontal scroll with touchpad does nothing

note.body: I was going to install Gimp to see if this behavior shows up in other applications built on GTK+ but it looks like they're still on 2.x, and Meld is on 3.x.  Do you happen to know of another common application that a) has prebuilt Windows binaries, b) uses GTK+ 3.x (preferably a similar version to Meld) and c) would have some UI element that needs horizontal scrollbars?  I'm not that familiar with the community, unfortunately.

events.target_title: Horizontal scroll with touchpad does nothing

note.body:
Woo hoo, I can confirm functional horizontal scrolling in Gramps!  Version is listed as "GrampsAIO64-4.2.8-1"; `gramps -v` lists GTK version 3.18.9.

To reproduce, create a new Family Tree, switch to the Families tab, and the top-left pane (a list of people, I guess?) scrolls horizontally when the window is small enough.  It works with my touchpad.

One other interesting thing: I just opened Meld and looked for other fields that might have horizontal scroll.  I found "File -> Format As Patch", which gives a single-pane editor in a resizeable modal window.  I assume this window is unlikely to have special hooks (like the ones to make the side-by-side editors scroll in tandem), but it too fails to respond to horizontal scroll.

So, maybe it's something that got fixed in a version of GTK between the one used in my (older, Windows) build and the one Gramps includes?  If that's the case, I guess there's nothing to do but wait until the mailing list figures out getting Windows builds back on track.


ETA: before I forget, [I think it might be possible to emulate horizontal scroll using AutoHotKey](https://superuser.com/questions/119877/emulate-mouse-wheel-scroll-with-keyboard), if you have a Windows system to test on but not one that supports touchpad scrolling.  I'm going to see about installing it and making sure it behaves the same way on my box.

Linux bytewiper 4.19.0-2-amd64 #1 SMP Debian 4.19.16-1 (2019-01-17) x86_64 GNU/Linux
```

events.target_title: Search instead of name modification in save window

note.body: I see this happening in any save and save as action. I strongly agree that this behavior is wrong for the save dialog. Especially as the name of the file to be saved is selected. So as user I expect when I type that the selected text (i.e., the file name will be replaced with my typing. But as the search is triggered I first have to cancel the search, then click into the filename text field and select the text to be replaced. This is really disturbing the workflow.

events.target_title: Redesign the file selection dialog

note.body: The search issue has also been reported with issue #36. And as I'm experiencing this nearly daily I would be extremely happy to get this fixed.

events.target_title: Mail view's magic spacebar executed even when the view is inactive
Redesign the file selection dialog

note.body:
As long time Gnome user and application developer I wanted also to add a comment regarding usability here:  I'm not to sure if it is a good idea that the file chooser should mimic more and more behavior of the file manager. Recently I noticed that when I was switching to another window during a save or load operation for looking something up I regularly misinterpreted the file chooser with nautilus and I wanted to do file manager operations in the file chooser. I would expect that I'm not alone with that issue. 

So from a usability perspective I think it would be better to keep both UIs clearly separated. And only allow the main file chooser tasks in the file chooser dialog.

events.target_title: Multi-touch touchpad scrolling not working
Multi-touch touchpad scrolling not working

note.body: Oh sorry. I experience it with 3.28.4 (Debian Testing).

events.target_title: Redesign the file selection dialog

note.body:
I find the recent directories a very good idea. I would really need that daily. 

One other thing that I'm more and more noticing is that the current save dialog is way to similar to the current nautilus. While this is nice for recognizing certain UI features it gets really problematic to know what you are currently doing.

This my sound odd in the beginning, but what I'm in the last month regularly experiencing is that during the save process of a document while I'm searching for a name or location I get distracted (i.e. need to move to a different virtual screen or window). When I then come back later I think this is a nautilus window and not the save dialog. If both would be more distinguishable from each other it would really help me in my workflow.

I quickly tested also the Gimp save dialog and i must admit there are lot of interesting details in.

events.target_title: Drag-select multiple messages
Markdown input syntax highlighting

GtkSpinner should spin even if animations are disabled

note.body:
> So maybe let's fix that and instead call it _a widget to indicate an ongoing operation, usually by an animated spinning icon_, or something. Other themes can use a static icon if they like, and they can use icons that may indicate indefinite progress better if not animating.

Sounds like an improvement, as long as that icon is not just the first frame of the spinner wheel. Everyone knows from experience that such a wheel icon is supposed to spin, and when it doesn't, it looks flat out broken and indicates the opposite of an "ongoing operation".

I still don't consider the spinner an animation in the same sense as, say, a window shrinking to a minimized state though. The spinner metaphor is ubiquitous on the web and people are so used to it that it is hard to imagine a better way of indicating that something is happening in the background. Thus I feel there is a strong argument for exempting the spinner from the animation switch.

events.target_title: Warn about potential homograph attacks

note.body:
@notafile Good to hear that Matrix already has some basic protection built in, however:

1. As described in the issue linked by @saparvia, display names are still vulnerable to homograph attacks as they apparently permit the entire range of Unicode characters.
2. With enough effort from the attacker, even IDs might still be vulnerable via the *server name*, at which point all considerations from classic IDN homograph attacks apply. Not all registrars disallow homograph domains.

Point 1 is definitely the more serious one though. Currently, almost every display name can be spoofed with minimal effort.

Implement type-ahead find for efficient file system navigation

note.body:
For me, the "use case" for type-ahead find is to *move* to some file, not to *search* for it. Removing type-ahead find for me just removes usability, for it leaves this use case uncovered.
> > it does seem you guys are unwilling to revert to the old type-ahead find behavior

> This is correct, remember this issue is closed. What we are doing here is trying to improve the current situation, with different solutions.

Please reconsider this decision.

> Let's try to keep this issue low noise, please.

@csoriano I believe people are rightly making noise because you are messing up with the tools they use.

note.body:
> Another way to achieve this goal is making search faster (#246) and more efficient (#247). That's the current design direction (see the ~"2. Stretch" label in both issues).

Making search faster and in general keeping the focus only on search, disregarding type-ahead find, is not a step towards finding a _compromise_ between the needs of old-time users and newbies who expect different behaviours (do they, really?). Be clear instead of trying to sell your “vision”.

Initial Sync never completes for large accounts/slow homeserver sync requests

note.body: Trying it out now..

events.target_title: Initial Sync never completes for large accounts/slow homeserver sync requests

note.body:
So this is still bugged, and the problem seems to be twofold:

1. Your first request is nice and lazy loaded, but the followup requests on timeout are full fat initial syncs which means that it not only takes as long, but Synapse throws away the lazy loaded initial sync.

2. The timeouts for requests are waaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaay too short. Each request is given a timeout of 30 seconds. You should NOT set a value for this and instead leave it up to the homeserver or the load balancer to kill the request. Doing requests every 30 seconds has an adverse effect on Synapse.

I'm sad to say that these bugs cause my homeserver to spin CPU and cause homeserver instability, and I've yet to manage to reach a full sync with Fractal.

events.target_title: Memory leak

note.body:
>  I hacked together an extension to limit the "damage" for those not willing to wait years for a proper solution:
> https://github.com/adee/gnome-shell-aggressive-gc

I just wanted to say thank you to @adee for this.  It seems to at least tame the beast.  I think the real issue is a combination of small memory leaks, fragmentation issues, and a way too lazy garbage collector.  Small leaks make fragmentation worse and the GC doesn't seem to kick in when it should.  This really helps and I highly recommend it until the other issues can be fixed.  Should maybe consider making this default behavior so I don't have to reboot in order to run Chrome and Android Studio at the same time (on an 8GB RAM machine).  While finding work-arounds may not be the ideal solution, its a step in the right direction since IU think the work-arounds will hilight where the deeper issues arise.

events.target_title: Make cloud integration the default experience

note.body:
I don't believe NextCloud would support inline media. Sure, an Android application might locally store a media then a note may create a link to this media. But i do not believe NextCloud is to develop syncing with this.

The philosophy of markdown is rather : "Readability, however, is emphasized above all else. A Markdown-formatted document should be publishable as-is, as plain text" (https://daringfireball.net/projects/markdown/syntax#philosophy ).

On the NextCloud site, https://apps.nextcloud.com/apps/notes ,  it states categories will be supported. I guess a larger set of application would be compatible with this approach.

Email may allow a larger feature set. Bastien Nocera once opened a ticket supporting storing Notes in a "Note" email folder. Some open source app would allow to work with this. This would allow inline media, and i bet we can find some app playing nicely with this. But probaly no categories, and worse, i am not sure this would be feasible easily.

You may also want to look at Turtl for the sake of comparison https://turtlapp.com/

Shift + Move tool immediately snaps object to (0,0)

note.body:
Can confirm still present in 2.10 (2.10.2, win64 build).

- Occurs *only* when holding down the SHIFT modifier in this tool.
- Occurs *regardless of* whether the Move tool is set to 'Pick' or 'Move' mode.
- Resolves itself automatically when the mouse is actually moved.

Fun but useless, try it:
- Zoom out so the canvas occupies a small area of the total image window.
- With the Move tool, hold SHIFT and click repeatedly.  With each click, the current object is moved inversely to the mouse's canvas position -- e.g. if the mouse is clicked at canvas (-100,0) then the object gets moved 100 pixels right.  Try clicking on various areas around (0,0) and watch the object move in all sorts of directions.

dav: Default max-conns-per-host for SoupSession limits open files to 2

note.body:
The actual number of files required to be visibly open is not necessarily 2. While I could always reproduce this bug by opening a third file, I've occasionally encountered it with fewer obviously open files; possibly, file manager activity (listing directories) counts to the maximum as well.

Thanks Cnly for finding this (I've spent hours debugging what I though was a gvfs-fuse problem before I found into gvfsd-dav and finally this issue). Please consider drastically increasing this limit or at least mitigating the blockage involved.

When it occurs, is there a better or more user friendly workaround than `pkill gvfs`?

events.target_title: dav: Default max-conns-per-host for SoupSession limits open files to 2

note.body:
In my tests, closing a file did suffice; however, in practice it may be hard to determine where one is open ("Is that vlc still accessing t at paused stream?").

Server side limits could indeed become an issue -- but is it actually necessary to keep a connection per open handle? Transfer happens in ranges anyway (say the server logs), so a single connection with pipelining should suffice for all streams. (Or 2-3 conns so that  quick questions like stat/ls can be answered w/o waiting for a range).

events.target_title: dav: Default max-conns-per-host for SoupSession limits open files to 2

note.body:
VLC uses GIO via fuse, that adds a layer of complexity.

My current test setup is `gio cat $FILE | hd` in parallel terminals. That works for two in parallel, but eg. Thunar locks up completely while the two are running, and Nautilus only spins idly on that network device. Stopping any of the two parallel cats causes the file managers to unblock correctly, or the third stream to start, whichever is pending.

Occasionally, however, (and that might be a different bug, but is IMO close enough to mention here) after file manager operations, a second stream does not start again, so that only one parallel cat works. Attempting to disconnect in such a situation gives me "Volume is busy" showing an empty list of applications using the share both from Nautilus and Thunar.

note.body:
I have tested some, and found that the crash can be fixed using the following patch:
(Not sure that this is the best solution, but this is at least a solution that avoids the crash).


```
--- a/lollypop/container_views.py
+++ b/lollypop/container_views.py
@@ -145,6 +145,8 @@
             if isinstance(child, SearchView):
                 child.set_search(search)
                 return child
+        if search is None:
+            search = ""
         view = SearchView()
         view.set_margin_top(MARGIN_SMALL)
         view.set_margin_start(MARGIN_SMALL)
--- a/lollypop/view_search.py
+++ b/lollypop/view_search.py
@@ -79,6 +79,8 @@
             Set search text
             @param search as str
         """
+        if search is None:
+            search = ""
         parsed = urlparse(search)
         search = search.replace("%s://" % parsed.scheme, "")
         if parsed.scheme == "local":

```

events.target_title: Writing and reading through Lollypop causes occasional file corruption
[Bug] Multi-disc albums only show album one
Writing and reading through Lollypop causes occasional file corruption

note.body:
The issue didn't let me go unmoved, so I have found a reliable way to reproduce it!

How to reproduce:
* Add a multi-part .flac converted album to your music folder, make sure it has no cover image
* Run `./flac -t *.flac` to ensure that all files are intact
* Start Lollypop and import the album
* Go to the album and open the new cover-image dialog
* Select an album
* *Pay attention to the file directory, as you see all kinds of meta_edits jumble around*
* Run `./flac -t *.flac` which will produce errors

Important to know, that if I change the album cover through kid3-qt, this issue doesn't occur, which gives me the strong impression that the Lollypop implementation is at fault.

What I also find interesting, is the folder behaviour. If you add an image using kid3-qt, you see it update every record once, in order of listing. When using Lollypop, it updates multiple records at the same time, but it also updates multiple records multiple times.

I previously also discovered this corrupting behaviour with mp3 files, but since mp3 doesn't have a checksum, it's harder to validate such errors.

If you need any help, like getting a particular album to test with, let me know. There were no errors logged though, so I can't share those with you.

events.target_title: If display in DPMS mode power button should wakeup display instead of suspend

note.body:
> If the device is a tablet, then the policy is to always suspend rather than doing DPMS off.

I never seen such behaviour on eight different tablets running Gnome Shell. I assume this is because hostnamed identify all this tablets as "Chassis: laptop". I wonder, where I can read how chassis detection supposed to work in hostnamed, besides setting it manually? 

I also think that "always suspend" policy would be right thing to do if we would have real "Connected Standby" implementation: https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows-hardware/design/device-experiences/integrating-apps-with-modern-standby (with features such as "apps can create background tasks by using a specific set of WinRT APIs that allow the task to execute on a regular schedule or in response to an incoming network event" and "Apps can also use timer-triggered background tasks to periodically check for new app-specific content during modern standby.")

But we doesn't have it, so this behaviour for example would interrupt voip conversation (I use my Dell 5855 LTE for VoIP calls via Bluetooth headset) prevent receiving IM or e-mail notifications, and doesn't allow to play music or podcast when screen is in DPMS. Thankfully, this is doesn't happen, because hostnamed identify tablets as laptops for now, but I guess this could be issue in the future?

events.target_title: Keyboard backlight level toggles to wrong state
Keyboard backlight level toggles to wrong state

note.body:
We check the `upower_kbd_toggle` function called in `handle_method_call_keyboard` when the event is **Toggle**, and find out it checks only the state of **old brightness** without **current brightness**.
That misses some other states changing.

events.target_title: Keyboard backlight level toggles to wrong state

note.body:
So, here is the list of the Toggle Method's state machines:
1. brightness_now: 0, brightness_old: 1 ~ max level of brightness
   -> toggle to old brightness
2. brightness_now: 0, brightness_old: -1 or 0
   -> toggle to max brightness
3. brightness_now: 1 ~ max level of brightness, brightness_old: don't care
   -> toggle to 0 brightness

System does send up both **KEY_KBDILLUMUP** and **KEY_KBDILLUMTOGGLE** with the same kot key.  It recognizes the current state and the steps of the keyboard backlight could be, then sends the corresponding event.
https://patchwork.kernel.org/patch/10376921/

The events mapping:
* **KEY_KBDILLUMUP** -> keyboard backlight **StepUp** in GNOME settings daemon
* **KEY_KBDILLUMTOGGLE** -> keyboard backlight **Toggle** in GNOME settings daemon

The reason is there is only one hotkey which can change the state of keyboard backlight and the brightness can be multiple steps.

events.target_title: Keyboard backlight level toggles to wrong state

note.body:
Actually, one, two or three keys is another question.

The keyboard backlight brightness **StepUp**, **StepDown** and **Toggle** events still can be sent by kernel.  It is defined by the API specification.  The `handle_method_call_keyboard` function in `gsd_power_manager.c` will execute **StepUp**, **StepDown** and **Toggle** corresponding actions separately.

We did find the **Toggle** bug by pressing the hotkey.  Then, dive into the codes and found states changing in the **Toggle Method**, which may be wrong for now.

Therefore, I file this issue and list the **state machines** which the **brightness_old** and **brightness_now** of keyboard backlight **Toggle Method** could be and focus on it.

More detail, the **Toggle Method** in GNOME settings daemon has to toggle keyboard brightness to the right state at least.

> So it looks widely different from everything else in the desktop. That's fine, and I don't see why this doesn't apply to window decorations as well. I expect them to be reasonable, not to perfectly match other decorations.

As a normal user, I cannot disagree more. I decide which look I want to have on my desktop. And every application has to follow this. An inconsistent look & feel is a major annoyance and is unprofessional from my point of view. Do you really want your users wasting time trying to fix something that can only be fixed with an acceptable result on your side? Yes, fonts, sizes, symbols, placements and layouts do matter a lot. So far I have just seen damage in other open source projects because of this endless *CSD is the only way* discussions. Feel free to provide a better solution but don't try to sell something as fine that doesn't work at all.

events.target_title: g_content_type_guess segfaults when passed an empty data buffer on Mac OS
g_content_type_guess segfaults when passed an empty data buffer on Mac OS

note.body:
As far as I can tell, that's incorrect. For the two functions that `xdg_mime_get_mime_type_for_data` calls, passing along `result_prio`:

`_xdg_mime_cache_get_mime_type_for_data` calls into `cache_get_mime_type_for_data`, which has this check: https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/blob/master/gio/xdgmime/xdgmimecache.c#L755-756

`_xdg_mime_magic_lookup_data` also has this check:
https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/blob/master/gio/xdgmime/xdgmimemagic.c#L699-700

So the fix should be to check if `result_prio` is `NULL` at https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/glib/blob/master/gio/xdgmime/xdgmime.c#L534

Custom header artwork for the app view
Custom header artwork for the app view

note.body:
> how would this artwork look alongside the screenshots on the page (since you don't want it to be too busy)?

Good question. Here are three mockups, from my colleague Spencer Bygraves, of how app views might look if the publisher provides both header artwork and screenshots. The screenshot area is quite separate:

![custom-1](/uploads/37112a0289a3ae32268814ad17c253f5/custom-1.png)

![custom-2](/uploads/403b08b247689dab9de71bdd3b7faad1/custom-2.png)

![custom-3](/uploads/57213bbe743429c4e2ffb8adb0227187/custom-3.png)

And here are three examples of how a generic header would look, based on an app-specific colour (whether the “dominant colour” you mention, or an automatically chosen one):

![generic-1](/uploads/1c1a7fd6396bc01cb91f82712bebb809/generic-1.png)

note.body:
> I'm a little less sold on the cut in outline of the bottom of each banner. It's not especially neat. I'd be happy to discuss that though.

It’s a bit odd that it implies the top of a rounded rectangle, without any hint of where it ends (nothing ◟_____◞-shaped at the bottom of the view).

I do think, though, that it would be a good thing for the contents to partly cover the header like this. (Your alternative C seems to achieve this too.) Besides looking more sophisticated, it would encourage publishers to use non-detailed photography or artwork where occlusion doesn’t matter (which is what we want, given that the window is resizeable), rather than detailed artwork or something akin to a banner ad.

If we went that route, I’d agree with @jimmac on using the current plain layout for apps that hadn’t provided artwork. But for option B or C, I think a colour auto-selected from the app icon would work well.

> In the above mockups it looks like we'd have a default image in greyscale and apply a tint to that. Please supply me with an appropriate image to use :)

From visual designer Lyubo:

> the background is composed of 2 parts:
>
> 1. linear gradient between 2 shades … for example linear-gradient(to right, `#29B360` 0%, > `#1D8045` 100%)

These are the colours that would be calculated from the app icon.

> 2. 3 transparent shapes … the size is 1200x199, but it can be resized or clipped as needed.

Here’s the transparent shapes file, as an SVG, so (like the gradient) it can scale to any window width.

![folds.svg](/uploads/ca8eda87692bd8f7e0a8ee1c750c1b3f/folds.svg)

Combining the shapes with the gradient, into a single SVG, would make it easier to swap out the whole design for something else, in exchange for making it more difficult to wrangle the colours per-app in code.

@jimmac Agreed for layout A. (But that’s not my favorite, for the reasons I gave.)

events.target_title: Application settings?

note.body:
> @aday, shouldn't we also have the reverse view, showing all applications that have access to e.g. the Camera and allowing revoking/granting access there? It seems that iOS also has both ways (via application or via permission) to see it.

Solving this will affect the overall UI structure, so addressing this early would save a lot of redesign later.

I think people will often want to switch between the two views, and will end up in a better privacy state if this is easy to do. For example, if you’re surprised to see that a particular app’s list of permissions includes camera access, you’d reasonably get curious about which other apps have camera access too. Conversely, if you’re reviewing the list of apps with access to Contacts, and discover an app that shouldn’t be there, it would make you wonder what other things that particular app has access to.

In iOS, switching between these two views is both non-obvious and slow. The route for the first example above has four steps (starting from the app’s settings view): Back, scroll, Privacy, Camera. And the route for the second example (starting from the “Contacts” view): Back, Back, scroll a long way, Name Of App. And both of those routes assume that you know, and remember, that the other view even exists; there are no signposts in either direction.

People are used to this inefficiency, because iOS in general is optimized for iPhones (iPads being a small minority), so the IA is optimized for small touchscreens: deep hierarchies and long scrolling lists of curtly-labelled items. On laptops and desktops, touchscreens are both rarer and fiddlier, so scrolling UI panels are much less efficient. But their much larger screens allow shallower hierarchies, controls like tables, tabs, and keyboard-navigable lists for much quicker exploration, and labels that have room to be more explanatory.

Here’s a UI I designed in February for browsing and changing app permissions:

![app-permissions.cropped](/uploads/708ae22aeafd0750ba0e594af6b92b61/app-permissions.cropped.png)

There’s no need to navigate anywhere to switch between the two views; just toggle the radio buttons. You can scroll through either list with the keyboard, without having to navigate in and out of dialogs. An app’s built-in permissions would be listed in the same listbox as its optional permissions (if they’re really “sysadmin-ish”, they could be at the bottom of the list). And if necessary, we could add a search/filter field to either listbox, with no risk of being confused with a search function for Settings as a whole (as it would be in [the layout posted above](https://gitlab.gnome.org/Teams/Design/settings-mockups/blob/master/applications/applications-wires.png)).

One thing missing from this design is the settings for which devices/files each app can access. But I don’t think the settings for which file _types_ and protocols each app handles should go here. For example, it doesn’t seem realistic to me that anyone would scroll past non-browser apps to find their current default browser, scroll past a bunch of stuff about things that the browser has access to, find the “Default Handler” “Web links” item, and click “Remove”. That kind of thing would be clearer in a single separate panel for default apps.

I was wrong. The location of `nemivercommon.db` is also hardcoded in [`get_user_db_dir()`][1] in a completely different file.

By the way, `nemiver.conf` is hardcoded _three_ times ([one][2], [two][3], [three][4]) across two differenti files (granted, these refer to three different files—respectively `~/.nemiver/config/nemiver.conf`, `./nemiver.conf` and `$LIBDIR/nemiver/config/nemiver.conf`). There are also two places that hardcode `nemivercommon.db` ([one][5], [two][6]) across two files. Is this really OK?

events.target_title: Change the default encryption method to the most compatible one (ZipCrypto)

note.body:
From a cryptographic standpoint, ZipCrypto is [fatally broken][1], even if perhaps [not broken enough][2] yet for a pratical attack .  It isn’t clear to me if the option should be provided at all, let alone as the default.  (The claim isn’t that the PR is wrong, but that the current implementation is, but the PR moves it towards the wrongness, not away from it.)

[1]: https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007%2F978-3-642-31912-9_16
[2]: https://crypto.stackexchange.com/q/19716

WIP: Port to meson build system
WIP: Port to meson build system

note.body:
Looks like we both faced the same issues :)

> I see you've divided gnome-games to an executable and a static library to link plugins against.

Yep, to have header and vapi file generated and installed, building a library seems the way to go for now.

> I've tried not to do that, and as a result: https://github.com/mesonbuild/meson/issues/3538

In fact, plugins are not really linked against the static library, it would have made huge ELF files otherwise.

Instead, I used `link_depends` keyword in place of `link_with`. It's a poor man trick to force gnome-games vapi file to be generated before plugins. The executable is the only one to be actually linked to the library (`link_whole`).

Until the issue you have reported is fixed and we can simply use the result of the executable, I cannot think of a better way to do this.

> Here's my version, if anything. It doesn't build cleanly atm because the plugins depend on the gnome-games vapi file that isn't present on clean build. When the bug is fixed, it would be done automatically with link_with: gnome_games_exec.

During the port, I tried to exactly match autotools behaviour. Hence, I used tri-state options to enable or not each plugin.

I see you have removed duplicates dependencies for plugins and main executable. I will cleanup and rebase my PR to do the same.

events.target_title: Migrate gtk-doc to GitLab including issues
ability to customize headers and footers in html output

note.body:
No rush. In any case, I'd like to keep the dependencies small. So one option is python string templates:
https://docs.python.org/3.1/library/string.html#template-strings

The tricky part is that the conversion is now procedural:
https://gitlab.gnome.org/GNOME/gtk-doc/blob/master/gtkdoc/mkhtml2.py#L1447
There is a function for each page type and a bunch of helpers. Most styling is done via css.

A footer using a template-string is probably not too difficult, since gtk-doc just ends the page blank. A header would be easy if all you want is to insert it above everything. But if you want to change the way the nav-header looks and have extra info there, its going to be complicated :/

note.body:
@antoniof 

> Do you have any file inside your `XDG_TEMPLATES_DIR`?

No, and after I installed my template files the submenu finally appears, which is out of my expectations.

Previously even when `XDG_TEMPLATES_DIR` is empty the menu still exists with a single option to create "an empty file", I would really like the behavior to stay the same (instead of "we are smart enough to know you don't have any templates so we hide the entire submenu for you")

events.target_title: Reserve the "New Document" submenu even when there's no templates available (was: "New Document" submenu support)

note.body: Files should at least support creating a "Plaintext Document" as it is a rudimentary file format and is useful in creating config files(i.e. `.bashrc`) and scripts etc. which often occurs to a Unix-like user.
